bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, November 26, 1923

div1.p: Hanson describes the ongoing yellow fever work in Colombia. He believes an outbreak is still possible, although there have been no confirmed cases. There has been extensive dengue fever in Barranquilla.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, November 26, 1923

FUNDACION ROCKEFELLER
JUNTA INTERNACIONAL DE SANIDAD
Barranquilla,
November 26,1923. My dear Doctor Carter:

Your letter of Oct. 12, Corrected Oct.29
has been received and read with the greatest interest. I think
this is one of the most interesting letters I have gotten from
even though they are all very interesting.

I made a copy of this letter and sent it to Dr. Garcia
Medina, who is a very great admirer of yours. Later we will trans-
late it and send copies of the translation to persons who are
properly interested in our work.

This evening I am leaving for Cartagena to help Corrigan
get things organized there. I have been planning to go there for
some time but have been unable to do so on account of Dr. Miller's
illness. He had what appeared to be a pretty severe case of dengue,
the rash came out on the 3rd day. We sent him to Dr. Drennen's
Clinica as we did not have things so arranged here as to take care
of him in our quarters here at the main office.

We are going ahead first with our organization of the
coast, with the plan to go on up the river from here. In the upper
river we already have the work going from Girardot to Puerto Berrio
Barranca-Bermeja and Puerto Wilches. On the coast we are working
Barranquilla, Cartagena, Puerto Colombia and will investigate Santa
Marta, with the idea of having a clean and non-infectable coast, thus
avoiding as much as possible quarantine difficulties, later to pro-
ceed up the river by way of Colomar, Magangue, etc., until we meet
the work from up the river. In addition to this we have the work
going in Cucuta, so you see we are about organized in so far as
the main defensive program for Colombia is concerned.

As the situation is at the present time we have an ex-
posed infectable territory in sufficiently close contact with the
Bucaramanga district for something to show up if there still is
Yellow fever in the country. I do not regard this territory with
any serious apprehension, and the fact of the matter is that I am
rather hoping that something might show up there, which would give
me just the weapon I need to push our present program with the
“gunpowder” behind it which is acking at the present time, with a
doubtful situation in Bucaramanga and nothing but rumors outside
to spur the people and the authorities along. Notwithstanding all
this we are getting ahead even better than I had hoped.

We have just completed the first rivisin of the entire
city of Barranquilla, and have an average house index of a little
over 51%. Some of the districts were started earlier as a conse-
quence of which the index in those has come done and helped to
bring the general index down to the figure which I have just quoted.

Since leaving Bucaramanga my time has been taken up with
travel and organization and I have not had time to make any
further detailed studies of cases of sickness. We have had what
appears to be quite an extensive epidemic of dengue here in
Barranquilla, but no cases have been reported to me by the local
medical profession as suspicious of yellow fever. There was one
case of illness in a man going from here to Santa Marta and from
there to the Canal Zone, took sich aboard after leaving here on
Nov. 11, left Santa Marta on the 13th and died in Colon Hospital
on the 16th with anuria. The Health Authorities there are divided
as to whether or not it was a case of yellow fever, as Fessler
wrote me they were a little more than 50% inclined to call it Y. F.
They stated however that they did not find albumen in the urine.
I have received no further details.

I sort of feel however that even incidents of this kind
bear us up in the justification of being on the coast for the pur-
pose of anticipating things of this kind.

Dr. Gregg of the I.H.B., has just been here and I have dis-
cussed the situation quite fully with him, presenting the possibili-
ties of what might happen and what I thought ought to be done and
what I might do under the different circumstances that he might ex-
plain the matter personally on arrival in New York.

There was a report that there had been two cases of supposed
yellow fever in Cartagena, and I am going there tonight as stated
to see what I can find aout.

Mrs. Hanson and the children are on the Canal Zone, but I
think that if I can get a suitable house I will bring them here
after Christmas. This is certainly a most unsatisfactoyr way of
living. I have been with my family less than six days in the last
six months.

I am having the matter of the books, which you want, looked
up.

We all here in the office are hoping for your speedy re-
covery and are looking forward with pleasure to reading your
history as well as many other things.

Very sincerely yours,
Henry Hanson
Regards to Laura.
H.
